bibl.title: Letter from P.S. Rossiter to the Surgeon General, October 1, 1899

div1.p: Rossiter reports on the recent epidemic of yellow fever at Cabana Fortress in Havana. He describes the patients and their symptoms as well as the disinfection of clothing, bedding, and property.

div1.head: Letter from P.S. Rossiter to the Surgeon General, October 1, 1899
div1.opener:
Ac
K
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
Field Hospital,
Camp Ludlow
October, 1st, 1899.
To the Surgeon General, U.S. Army,
Washington, D.C.,
Sir:-
div1.p:
In complance with par. 119. Manual for the Medical Department, 1899, I have the
honor to make the following report of the recent epidemic of Yellow Fever occurring
at Cabana Fortress, Havana, Cuba. and at Camp Ludlow near Cabana Fortress to which the
occupants of that post were removed to check the progress of the infection.

On August 10th, 1899, Priv. Jas. Dougharty, Batt. “B”. 2nd, Art. presented himself at
the Post Hospital having had a slight chill at 12 M. associated with nausea and vomiting
and intense pain in the head and lumbar region. Temperature on admission 103 F.
Pulse 110. Temperature throughout the following 24 hours ranged between 102 and 103.5
Pulse 110 to 80. His conjunctivae were greatly injected, face and neck congested
and gums slightly puffy. A diagnosis of Yellow Fever was made and albumen 4% appear-
ing in the urin on the following morning, he was transferred to Las Animas Hospital.
This man positively denies having been absent from the post for a period of 10 days
previous to his attack, and the Battery records corroborate his statement.

At 8.30. P.M. Aug. 11th, Priv. Timothy Realy, Batt. “E”, was admitted to the hospital.
He had had a slight chill at 11 A.M. nausea, no vomiting, intense pain in head and
lumber region. Temperature on admission, 102.8 E. Pulse 105, conjunctivae suffased.
Face and neck congested. During the following 20 hours his temperature ranged between
101.5 and 103.5 F. Pulse steadily falling to 70. A diagnosis of Yellow Fever was
made and on Aug. 12th, he was transferred to Las Animas Hospital. No albumen appeared
in his urine before his transfer.

The clothing of these men and the barrack rooms in which they slept were at
once disinfected with Formaldehyde and Bichloride of Mercury solution; also the other
barrack rooms, Officers quarters, store rooms etc.

No other suspicious cases occurred until Aug. 20th, when Priv. Reed Lucas, Batt. K.
presented himself at the Hospital at 2 P.M., Temp. 103.8 F. Pulse 114.

Corp. Henry E. Clay, Batt. K, had been sick in quarters and Hospital, off and on for
two weeks on account of acute Bronchitis. On Aug. 20th, he was re-admitted
for the same cause, Temp. normal, Pulse 50. At 3 P.M. that date he had a slight chill
Temp. rapidly rising to 102.6 F. Pulse 95. Vomiting occurred at 6 P.M.

For the following 24 hours, his temp. ranged between 103 and 104 F. Pulse falling
to 82. During this time Priv. Luces' temperature had rises to 104.8 F. Pulse falling
to 84. Albumen appeared in the urine of both men on the evening of the 21st, A diag
nosis of Yellow Fever was made, and on the following morning they were transferred.

On Aug. 22nd, at 7 A.M. Priv. Clifford Calhoun, Batt. B, was admitted to the Hospital,
Temp. 101.5 F. Pulse 102. He had a slight chill at 3 (A.M.) nausea and vomiting,
headache, and pain in the back and legs. At 12 N. and 3 P.M. of the same day, the
vomited matter contained 1-2 ounce of bright blood.

During the following 24 hours his temperature ranged between 100.8 and 103 F.
Pulse steadily falling to 45. On Aug. 24th, On Aug. 24th, he was transferred, at which
time his urine showed a trace of albumen.

On Aug. 25th, at 6 P.M. Priv. Ed. Vragel, Batt. I, was admitted to the Hospital. He had
had a chill, nausea and vomiting at at 1 A.M. but made no mention thereof, until
the time of his admission to the Hospital, at which time he had Temp. 103.4 F. Pulse
120. On the following morning his Temp. was 102.5 F. Pulse 88; albumen 2% showing in
the urine; whereupon he was transferred.

On Aug. 26th, Sgt. Richard Graves, Batt E, was admitted to the Hospital at 7 A.M. Temp.
102 F. Pulse 106, chill at 9 P.M., headache, pain in the back and legs, eyes markedly
injected. During the following 48 hours his temperature ranged between 99.6 and 102.4
F. Albumen appeared in the urine on Aug. 27th, and on Aug. 28th, he was transferred.

It having been decided by the Commanding General, Dept. of Havana, Chief Surgeon, and
Post Surgeons that, in order to check the spread of the infection, it would be ad-
visable to move the Command into camp, the move was begun on Aug. 28th, and a camp
was pitched about three quarters of a mile N.E. of Cabana, and about 200 yds. from the
Gulf, the men sleeping in camp the night of Aug. 29th,.

Several days were required for the disinfection and removal of clothing and
property and, in doing this, details from the various batteries were obliged to enter
the Fort at intervals, until Sept. 3rd,, when the gates were closed and locked.

On Aug. 29th, Priv. Clyde Sheets, Batt. I, appeared at the Hospital, headache and nausea
no chill; he was admitted at 3 P.M. Temp. 103 F. Pulse 112. No albumen appeared in his
urine before his transfer on Aug. 30th, P.M.

On Aug. 21st, at 8 A.M. Priv. Chas. Shumway, Batt. E. appeared at sick call; slight
chill at 2 A.M. nausea and vomiting, intense headache and pain in lumbar region, Temp.
102.2 F. Pulse 95. He was transferred the same afternoon.

Priv. Jesse Hilton, Batt. E. was admitted to the Hospital at 11 P.M. Aug. 31st, Temp.
103,6 F. Pulse 104. He had a chill at 9 P.M. while on guard, followed by nausea but no
vomiting. During the following 36 hours his temperature ranged between 101.2 and
104 F. Pulse falling to 70.

Sgt. Newton Goodwin, Batt. I, and Priv. John Thorsby, B.C. were admitted to the Hos-
pital at Sick Call, Sept. 1st, Goodwin, Temp. 102.4 F. Pulse 84, no chill, conjunctivea
injected, slight nausea, Temp. during 36 hours 100.6 and 103 F. Pulse falling to 65.

Priv. Thorsby had been employed in nursing about two thirds of the cases of
Yellow Fever which had been admitted to the Hospital, as he was the best suited member
of the H.C. for such nursing. Great care was exercised however to prevent infection
of nurses and others; methods will be described elsewhere in this report.

On admission his temperature was 103.4 F. Pulse 118. Slight chill at 3 A.M., con-
junctivea injected, slight nausea and vomiting. Temp. and Pulse falling during 36 hours
to 101 F. and 58. Albumen appeared in the urine of these cases on the morning of
Sept. 2nd, on which day they were transferred.

On Sept. 3rd, were admitted four cases; Albert J. Adams, a civilian connected with
the Y.M.C.A. and living with the Command, at 7 A.M.; Priv. J. Rogers, Batt. E. 6 P.M.; Corp.
Mitchell, Batt. B, at 9 A.M.; and Priv. Daniel Coleman, Batt, K, at 4 P.M. Adams-no chill,
intense headache and pain in calves of legs, conjunctivea slightly injected, Temp. 102 F
Pulse 106, rising during 30 hours to 103.4 F. and Pulse falling to 54. Albumen 12% appea
appeared on the following morning; he immediately entered a semi-comatose state from
which he was never fully aroused. Transferred the following day.

Mitchell-no chill, conjunctivae slightly injected, slight headache and pain in
lumbar region, Temp. 102 F. Pulse 70, falling during 30 hours to 101.4 F. and 54. Albumen
2% appeared in the urine the following morning, during which evening he was transferre

Coleman-no chill, no nausea, intense headache and pain in lubar region coming on
at 3.30 P.M. Temp. 103.8 F. Pulse 140, falling to 101.5 F. and 105 during 48 hours
when he was transferred. No albumen before transfer.
Rogers- slight chill at 3 P.M. headache, nausea and vomiting, conjunctivea injected,
face and thorax congested. Temp. 104.2 F. Pulse 120. During the following 36 hours
his temperature ranged between 103 and 104.6 F. and pulse fall to 106. Albumen 5%
appeared on the morning of Sept. 4th, and increased to 6% on Sept. 5th, when he
was transferred.

On Sept. 4th, were admitted, Priv. F. E. Cilliams, Batt. B. at 8 A.M., Crisance Sgt.
Z. T. Woodall at 11 P.M., Priv. Ernest Rubeck, Batt. K, at 13 M. and Priv. Linsay M. Cocksay,
Batt. K. at 3 P.M.

Williams.-chill at 4 A.M., nausea and vomiting, intense pain in head and legs,
Temp. 104.6, Pulse 90. Temperature and pulse falling during 36 hours to 103.6 F. and
70. Albumen 2% appeared on the second morning, upon which day he was transferred.

Woodall.-no chill, slight headache, no nausea, or vomiting, Temp. 102.5 F. Pulse
108. He gave a history of chronic interstitial nephritis and, during the day, the
urine showed 60% of albumen. Temp. and pulse falling to 101.8 F. and 73 during 31
hours at which time he was transferred.

Rubeck.-chill at 9 P.M., nausea and vomiting, increasing prostration, Temp. 102.4
F. Pulse 100, falling to 101.8 F. and 69 during 30 hours. Conjunctivae injected,
albumen 2% on morning of 5th, upon which day he was transferred.

Cooksay.-no chill, headache and pain in back and legs coming on during after--
noon, no vomiting. Temp. 102.8 Pulse 104. falling to normal and 62 on the evening of
Sept. 5th, rising again on the morning of Sept. 6th, to 101.4 F. and 100, and ranging
between 103.4 and 102 F. and pulse falling to 70 until 3 P.M. Sept. 8th, when he was
transferred.

On Sept. 5th, 2nd, Lieut. Stanley D. Embick, Batt. B. while visiting the city on
business was wet through by the rain and his clothing allowed to dry on him. One
hour later he had a sever chill and a half hour later another chill. At the close
of the second chill, 4 P.M. Temp. 101 F. Pulse 100. Intense headache and pain in lumbar
region, nausea and vomiting, conjunctivae profusely injected. Temp. rising at 6 P.M. to
104.4 F. and pulse falling to 90. Temperature falling to 102.6 F. and pulse rising
to 95 on the following day, when he was transferred.

On Sept. 6th, Priv. Sernhardt Kraemer, Batt. K, appeared at sick call. Slight chilll
at 9 P.M., Temp. on admission 100 F. Pulse 102, conjunctivae slightly congested.
Vomiting occurred soon after admission, Temp. rising to 103.8 F. and pulse falling to
78. Albumen, a trace appeared on the following morning, temperature falling to 102.8
F. pulse remaining at 78. Transferred on Sept. 7th,.

The last case of the epidemic was that of Hans Hansen, Priv. Batt E, who present-
ed himself at the Hospital at 4 P.M. Sept. 8th, Temp. 102, Pulse 108, no chill; intense
headache and pain in back coming on about 2 P.M. Conjunctivae well injected. Vomiting
occurred twice during Sept. 9th,. Temp. fell 99 F. at 9 P.M. on Sept. 8th, pulse 70;
ranging between 99 F. and 100.6 F. throughout the follwing day. On Sept. 10th, the
temperature rose to 102.8 F. pulse remaining at 70, and from thence gradually
fell reaching normal on Sept. 11th. Albumen 5% appeared on the morning of
the 10th, increased to 10% on the 11th, and then gradually decreased, disappearing
on Sept. 15th. Prostration did not occur to a marked degree.

This patient was not transferred, but was treated in an isolated tent near the
Hospital. A mercurial purgative and Quinia Sul. gr.xxi were given him on admission,
followed by Magnesium Sul. 1-2 oz. the following morning. Nothing was permitted to
enter his stomach thereafter except iced Appollinaris water until Sept. 13th, when
a milk diet was cautiously commenced and gradually increased.
He was discharged from the Hospital as well on Sept. 21st,.

Before moving into camp all the personal effects of officers and men-with the
exception of the actually worn by them-, all bedding, Quartermaster property and
clothing were exposed in sealed casemates for four hours to the action of formal-
dehyde. then hauled into camp.

The men, before opening their lockers, stripped in the Company streets and made
their remaining clothing into bundles which were hauled into the Fort and disinfected
in the same manner. They then entered their tents and put on their previously disin-
fected clothing from their lockers.

All possible precautions were taken to prevent infection of the Hospital
quarters and attendants.

The bedding of the patients was changed at least every 24 hours, and immediately
immersed in a 1-1000 Bi-chloride solution. All feces and vomited matters were
received in an 8% Carbolic solution.

Nurses, after handling a patient were instructed to wash their hands in a 1-1000
Bi-chloride solution. After each patient was removed from the room, it was disinfec-
ted with formaldehyde and Bi-chloride solution. The mattresses, blankets, bedding, etc.
used by the patients, and the clothing and effects of the deceased were burned by
order of the Chief Surgeon and Post Commander.
The route by which infection entered the command is doubtful.

The Battalion had been quartered in Cabana Fortress since May 15th, two months
and twenty days before the first case of Yellow Fever appeared. No decided climatic
changes had taken place during that period which could have had any effect upon the
development of the infection.

About two thirds of the command was composed of recruits who had arrived in
Cuba after June 10th, but no dispropotion existed among the men attacked by the
fever between the recruits and the men who had been on the island since January 1st.
All the men attacked stated positively (and the Post records confirm their state-
ments) that they had not been off the reservation for at least ten days previous to
entering the Hospital.

The slow and insidious progress of the epidemic, together with the length of
time during which the command had occupied the Fortress, previous to the first
appearance of the Fever, would lead us to beleive that the infection had been intro-
duced from without, but, when we consider the fact that none of the men attacked had
been away from the Post for a period of ten days previous to the onset of the diseas
that the cases appeared in “B” Battery, then “B”, then “K”, then “B” again, and then “I”,
the barrack rooms of the Batteries not being in the sequence of infection, that none
of the Corral men nor Q.M. employes, who did not sleep in the Post, were attacked, and
that no case occurred after communication with the Fort had been cut off for six
days, I beleive the only conclusion at which we can arrive is that the infection was
derived from somewhere within the Fort.

Of the 23 cases occurring during this epidemic, 10 had their onset between 6 A.M
and 6 P.M. Eight had no manifestation of an initiatory chill. Abumen appeared in the
urine of 13 of the cases within 30 hours from the onset; in 3, within 40 hours; in
4, within 70 hours, and in one case not for 3 days.
Of the 23 men attacked, 8 died, a mortality of 34.8%.

Of those who died, only 2 had been addicted to the use of alcoholic liquors; 6
were under 30 years of age. All were previously strong and hearty. In none of these
cases did congestion of the gums appear to a marked degree before their transfer.
One case wherein infection was acquired in Cabana Fortress did not develop until
arrival in the United States. Prvt. Hy.S. Waggoner, Batt. I, bought his discharge and
left the Post on Aug. 20th. Upon arrival in New York he was feeling badly, but was
allowed to his home at Vincennes, Ind. He died the day after his arrival there, Sept.
1st, and, upon post-mortem, a diagnosis of yellow fever was made. This information
is derived from the Vincennes papers, no official notice of it having been received
here.

Pvt. Dougherty, after being returnef to the command from Las Animas Hospital was
admitted to the Field Hospital on account of his diet. As he was allowed to walk
about the camp for excercise exercise, he had been carefully warned to eat nothing
except the diet furnished at the hospital. Four days after his return, disregarding
the warning, he messed with his battery, afterwards going to the Canteen and eating
cakes and a pound of raisins and drinking soda pop and native brandy. Since that
night his temperature has ranged between 102 and 104.5 F. and he has fallen into
a typhoid condition from which he will probably not recover. (Widal reaction nega-
tive).

Before concluding this report, I cannot neglect to express my gratitude for the
efficient services of Actg. Asst. Surgeon M.A.W. Shockley, my confrere throughout the
epidemic, and my admiration for the conduct of this detachment of the Hospital
Corps. The Corps men were non-immunes, and, when I asked for volunteers among them
to nurse the Yellow Fever cases. every one instantly volunteered and conducted
themselves with an earnest and cheerful devotion to their duties throughout as
great a danger to themselves as was faced by any of our troops in battle.
In concluding. Sir. I have the honor to remain.
div1.closer:
Very truly
Your obedient servant (Signed) P. S. Rossiter
Actg. Asst. Surgeon, U.S.A.
Surgeon in Charge.
